data.content: A Beginner’s Guide to CART

Ever wondered about how a human brain works while making a decision? The endless possibilities to be comprehended before going down any road, all the mental calculations it performs regarding the rewards and the penalties that must be considered for achieving the best possible route to a decision. Yes, our brain, truly is a masterpiece and we’ll discuss how we can teach our computer the art of decision making.

Decision Trees are a predictive tool in supervised learning for both classification and regression tasks. They are nowadays called as CART which stands for ‘Classification And Regression Trees’. The decision tree approach splits the dataset based on certain conditions at every step following an algorithm which is to traverse a tree-like graph from root to leaf. At every stage, the nodes of the tree represent the possible test cases for the problem and following along any edge of a node represents a possible solution.

Decision Trees
Let’s see what a decision tree looks like.
https://miro.medium.com/max/1752/1*nLKcNuEEN8vFto9paF2Acw.png

The diagram illustrates a simple scenario of decision making wherein a person has to decide if he/she is eligible to cast a vote. So, the decision tree starts at the root trying to see the possibilities of making a decision based on the user’s input. Here, it’s a classification problem where a person becomes eligible to vote only if he/she is a citizen of the nation and is above 18 years of age.
You might be thinking right now that this can be implemented using a simple if-else statement in any programming language. But, I assure you it is much more complicated than that.

When it comes to huge and complex datasets there are a variety of parameters to be considered while making decisions throughout the tree. Hence, decision trees come to our rescue to aid us in making these decisions for us.
Let’s see a practical example where we will predict if a person can be hired or not based on their attributes.

Inference

Let’s analyze the decision tree we just obtained which is crucial in understanding how this algorithm works. At any point going down the right side of the tree depicts that a person is hired and going down on the left, depicts that the person is not. An observation can be made that a person who has ‘Employed?’ column with a value >0.5 is instantly hired. A person whose ‘Employed?’ column has a value of less than 0.5 but has a value greater than 0.5 in the ‘Interned’ column is hired. Similarly, other nodes in the tree can be evaluated. The tree has certain metrics which it has set for itself to make decisions gradually while traversing down the tree.
Predictions
Random Forest

Random Forest is nothing but a multitude of decision trees. It takes the number of trees as input and generates that many combinations of decision trees. Finally, the prediction is based on the mode in case of classification or the mean in case of regression.

Result

We see that in the first case, the person who was highly qualified with his/her features for the job didn’t even have to go all the way down the decision tree and was immediately classified as hired. In the second case, The person didn’t meet the features that were required for the company to be hired.

On running predictions for multiple test cases, we can observe that sometimes the value that is predicted changes. This is because the random forest classifier method considers randomly generated trees each time it runs. This is completely normal as we are just using 14 entries in our made-up dataset. With an increase in the size of the dataset, there are increasingly different combinations to be considered which can enhance the purity of the decision tree.
Yay! 🙌 We just built a decision tree that can predict if a person can be hired based on their attributes.
